name: Sea Lavender
climate: Sea Lavender thrives in a maritime climate, where conditions are mild and humid.
It prefers temperatures that don't drop too low or rise too high, maintaining consistency.
This plant can tolerate some salty conditions, commonly found in coastal regions.
While adaptable to a range of climates, it does best in regions without harsh extremes.
sunlight: Sea Lavender requires full sunlight to flourish, as it is naturally found in open areas.
Though it can tolerate some partial shade, full sun will ensure optimal blooming.
Extended exposure to direct sunlight aids in maintaining its vibrant flower color.
If grown indoors, place near a south-facing window to ensure ample light exposure.
watering: This plant does not require heavy watering; allow soil to dry between waterings.
Water moderately, ensuring the soil doesn't become waterlogged, to prevent root rot.
During the growing season, regular watering is beneficial but should not be excessive.
In winter, reduce watering frequency as the plant enters a dormant phase.
soil: Sea Lavender thrives in well-draining, slightly sandy soil, avoiding moisture retention.
A slightly alkaline to neutral pH is ideal, mimicking its natural coastal habitat.
Soil enriched with organic matter can support healthy growth, balancing texture.
Ensure the soil allows excess water to drain quickly to prevent root-related issues.
extra_care_tip: Deadhead spent flowers to encourage prolonged blooming and maintain visual appeal.
Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and suppress weed growth.
